text: I read the the conscience of a
conservative by Goldwater and uh I guess
he didn't really write the book but he
approved it and it was a terrific read
it still is uh to this day and it did
influenced me it it made me a limited
government person a constitutionalist
and uh and from that you you know you
you get involved with people who agree
with you on those issues and learn from
them about uh Ludwick Von misus fa Hayak
Ian Rand those I read all those people's
books and um and became very much a
Libertarian I don't think that I was uh
affected by the uh what was actually
going on in societ so much as I
was attracted to the logic of what he
was saying that people should be uh left
alone and that the role of government
was to protect your rights to life
liberty and the pursuit of happiness and
uh and I find that I found that very
compelling I ended up going to Berkeley
and saw um you know kind of uh u
a attitude that the law didn't matter uh
in some some of the the stins and and
certainly the riots and so forth and um
so that reinforced My Views um but um
I've I've always thought I was a
Libertarian I I always um believed that
there
was no justification for other people
telling you how to live your life and um
and subsequently learned about the
importance of private property and the
rule of law and so forth but um I think
uh you know my father was a conservative
so I disagreed with him on a lot of
things my mother was apolitical but I've
always been a
Libertarian well I ran for Student
Government at Berkeley on a platform of
abolishing the student government and I
thought that was pretty radical but I
actually uh lost the election U but
those were there those were tough tough
years for those who believed in less
government on on the Berkeley campus but
um um and so um I got involved with the
Goldwater campaign in 1964 I was a
member of Youth for Goldwater at
Berkeley which was a small group and I
actually was a Precinct Captain for two
precincts in uh Berkeley and I knew
every single voter who was going to vote
for uh Barry Goldwater there
was um five in one District I think and
six in and the other and uh it was uh
you know but I'd knock on everyone's
door in the precincts and you there were
for the most part um civil to me but
some were h a little hostile um and then
goldwater's campaign itself disappointed
me he had originally said we need to
privatize uh Social Security and um and
then backed away from it very shortly
thereafter and I thought he was I always
thought he was too hawkish about Vietnam
so I figured you know I'm out of
politics I'm a Libertarian all there is
out there is conservatives and liberals
and I don't buy into either camp and so
I was going to get out of it and I went
to work uh for Scutter Stevenson Clark a
um investment firm um and uh then was U
my loyalty to Scutter ended when allian
Capital offered to double my salary and
so I went to work for them and
um and
eventually um I got involved with the
libertarian party there in
19 uh 71 the libertarian party um had
its founding convention at the Rison
Hotel in Denver Colorado and I went to
that and I was I was like the only
person with a suit on and as a
Libertarian I always knew it was
important to be tolerant of alternative
Lifestyles but I always say until I went
into to that convention hall I had no
idea how many Alternatives there were it
was it was a a really weird it was like
a a Star Wars bar
scene they had you know randians with
long cigarette holders and gold bugs and
anarchists and uh gay rights activists
and uh and and and and some hardcore
conservatives who were still in favor of
the war in Vietnam uh but it was an
Eclectic group and they all shared this
kind of commitment to Liberty and I
found myself uh attracted to it and I
went back to California and and flipped
a coin with a friend and lost and became
the vice chairman of the uh libertarian
party of California I had 12 districts I
I organized and U drove all around the
southern part of the
state and um and and got involved and
then in 1974 I was elected National
chairman of the party and I kind of ran
it really through 1980
